Just playing around with the Minkowski formalism, there is evidently more than one way to travel faster than light. Let's guess that an entity could have an oscillation in one of the ways, and be in tachyonic Brownian motion in the other way which is orthogonal. TBM is often practically invisible, but it has an effect when matter interacts with the electromagnetic field which gives an outcome where a penny lands either heads or tails, or a cat is either dead or alive, and neither is ever in any superposition of states.

TBM means that when we integrate the SE, we need to make a random choice between a spacelike and a timelike integration. Entanglement does not* mean the particles communicate instantaneously; it means they are correlated in a very precise, non-classical way that's difficult to explain without going through the math.  There is in fact a theorem in quantum mechanics called the No Communication Theorem that shows you can't communicate with entangled particles.  It's unfortunate that we use this incorrect language of "communication" in science popularization.

Ok, so I don't know why this is always explained as though it's some sort of magic. The quantum system has only one internal state at any given time - we represent it as a vector in a vector space. It's ONE VECTOR, and it evolves in time per a differential equation like all the other stuff we're familiar with.

The problem is that we can't see that state. We can measure various quantities and get various results. Each of the results that it is possible for us to get also corresponds to a specific vector in the vector space, but not all of the vectors are accounted for. It's like having a clock that can only read out 9am or 12pm - it just can't show you any other times. The other times can still exist, as in it can "actually be that time," but for whatever reason we can only SEE 9am and 12pm. Now say the actual time is 10:30am. That's exactly halfway in between 9am and 12pm. So when we "measure" the time, we have a 50% chance of getting 9am, and a 50% chance of 12pm. Oh, and when we get one of those values, the system is forced to adopt that time as well. So it's 10:30, and we measure - we get 12pm. Now the system says it's 12pm.

There was never more than one actual state inside the system. It was never the case that it was 9am and 12pm at the same time - it was 10:30am up until we measured, and 12pm after we measured. It's just that our ability to assess the system is limited to just a subset of the vectors that can represent the internal state.

I wonder how many viewers remember what kind of particles show quantum entanglement after you put hundreds of "quantum entangled kittens" in their brain. Hint: Kittens can not be quantum entangled even if you try real hard. ;) Schrodinger's mind experiment (explaining what probability is while staying close to the "half-life" term, with one object changing state and its observation) doesn't apply well here, because the problem in observing quantum entanglement needs you to observe two objects (preferably far apart excluding relevant direct force influences) at the exact same point in time. It also doesn't matter if they were hidden from observation before, so the box doesn't apply. It's more like you check via perfectly synchronized video connections (quite impossible) on two "entangled kittens" playing in distant locations and one always looks in the exact opposite direction of the other. ... although the kittens are just a random object in this thought, so the effect isn't a lot easier to grasp with a kitten than with any other object like let's say an electron. ;) What I would like to know is why the guys you interviewed think they can show quantum entanglement with a) an experiment setup so fragile that it reacts to minor alignment variations of the detector (although there should be more significant variations in the long travel through air distance of the laser beam) and b) why they think they can fix that with having the detector auto aligned with random star light variations. The thing about testing is not about being sceptical, it is about being curious.

What happens under these new circumstances?

Most of the time, thing go according to plans and the physical laws as we know them.

When things however are not behaving as predicted, we are sceptical about the accuracy of the results, we do more tests to see if we can get repeats. And some times we find the flaws in the test (faster than light neutrinos) or there is just no way to repeat the results and we have to write it off as an unknown anomaly in the test setup and measurement.

Once we have verified results, we start looking at tweaking the laws as we know them to handle this new case, without invalidating everything else. This last part is quite important.

Skepticism is not about throwing away the old, it is about questioning the new data, until it is verified.

I notice I am confused. My intuition - the way I grapple with the concepts outlined in quantum mechanics that are difficult to attach to my day-to-day life - is to treat time as if it's something only multiparticle systems believe in. It's funny to say it that way, but if a fundamental particle isn't interacting with anything else, time has no effect on it. So, for a photon, every aspect of its existence happens one right after another. Emission, passage, and absorption as a series of events one after the other. It doesn't matter to the photon that 600 years have passed during the passage phase, or that it has had its energy colocated in space by being emitted as a tangled pair (or larger grouping, possibly), emission and absorption are where things start and end.

This means that when you do experiments that involve something outside of the system interacting with a photon, the rules being followed to enact it don't involve time as part of the equation. The period between emission and absorption is more-or-less undivided with everything that will be done to that photon happening to the same piece of information simultaneously. The lack of local hidden variables makes this interpretation more likely-seeming, since we are almost completely sure that the photon isn't storing any information about what's happened to it inside of itself somehow.

Non-fundamental objects have their properties, like chemistry, heat , and conductivity, determined by the arrangement of fundamental particles making them up. A subatomic particle has its identity determined by the arrangement of its quarks, but there don't appear to be any fundamental particles that are phase or spin in the way that vibration is heat, and electron shells are things like chemistry and conductivity. Bell's experiment was designed to figure out if there was something that science was unaware of that did these things for photons and electrons and whatnot. As the video says, the answer is "no" in any way we can determine. There is nothing about one photon that makes it different from any other photon. The things that differentiate photons (Frequency, polarization and spin) are due to their interactions with other things.

So, a photon that is in-transit where it isn't interacting with anything doesn't have anything to exist against. If something is being done that influences how a photon behaves while it's in transit, things like causality just don't get brought up. Some experiments bear this out, with one part of an entangled pair of photons being absorbed in such a way that a measurement can be made, while the other half continues to travel until it's put through an apparatus that biases the particle towards one state or the other and measures it. Even though the influence happened after the first half no longer exists, the pair of particles almost always will measure out as agreeing or disagreeing as expected. The influence impacts the already-absorbed photon that doesn't exist any more because "transit time" is a single event, so anything that happens during transit impacts all parts of a photon equally.

You're already thinking of FTL communication and you're not the millionth person to do so. None of the methods we have to influence the behavior of a pair of entangled photons can encode information. They're all probablistic and there's no way to make sure that a specific group of photons behave in a coherent enough way to be read as a signal. We know how a particular particle would look at the far end if it was measured at near end, but there's no method that can make all the photons you're sending be measured one way or the other. All of the methods are pretty random and will spit out random noise if you look for a signal.

Entanglement can be understood this way:  all matter below around 120 atomic weight on it's own devices will be in the state of EM (electromagnetic) wave energy.  There is no such thing as a particle below a certain atomic weight, it it's natural state.  the wave becomes a particle when disturbed/observed. Think of it as you blow a bubble and it floats as a perfect sphere (wave movement) until it is popped by a disturbance.  If you've ever seen a balloon pop in slow motion, the sheath (circumphercial sphere) actually retreats around the empty air of the sphere until it becomes a blob of rubber (the particle instead of the bubble) at the place opposite of wherever it was popped.  Back to waves.  All waves "travel" as in sinusoidal movement - upcrest, peak, change direction, down to center, negative crest, to negative peak, change direction, back to center.  Quantam entanglement is this:  by necessity, if this side of a wave starts as an upwards moving peak, the other end will be the negative peak returning to zero.  Top peak one side, negative peak other side.  Simple enough?  Now, why is distance does NOT affected by time? Well, which reference frame are you in? To you, it takes the speed of light to go from your location to the other end of that EM wave.  To you, if the wave is one light second long, you wonder why in time zero, if you "pop" (cause the wave to precipitate into a particle) one side if spin up (up crest) will cause in zero time, spin down on the other, there should be no mystery to understand.  From your reference point, it should take one second, but it happens instantly, so you think the information is going at super luminal speed, but it is NOT.  In the reference frame of the wave, travelling at light speed, all waves precipitate in time zero, because, as you approach the speed of light, time slows down.  But, to the wave itself, going the speed of light, time has STOPPED.  That's right, no matter how long a wave travels (without being and until it is disturbed/observed), it's span of distance occurs in NO TIME, within it's own reference frame, travelling at the speed of light.  Deep breath. So hopefully, this is nothing mysterious, just really, really cool stuff that we need to learn how to use to our advantage.  I love thinking about this stuff!  PS - just purchased my acoustical levitation kit!  Thanks for introducing me to that Physics Girl!

The Schrödinger
cat concept in the interpretation of Quantum Mechanics, generated
a discussion among physicists that persists from the beginning of quantum
theory to the present day: "Does Quantum Mechanics depend on human
observation?" This view of dependence was advocated slightly by
Schrödinger, but was strongly endorsed by Werner Heisenberg and the Danish
physicist Niels Bohr (hence this view is also known as "Copenhagen
interpretation"), and is currently dominant in Quantum Physics, although
many do not agree with this view and consider the opposite. See, for example: 1
- Robert B. Griffiths – “Consistent Histories and the Interpretation of
Quantum Mechanics” – Journal of Statistical Physics, v36, July 1984, https://doi.org/10.1007/BF01015734,
and 2 - Sheldon Goldstein – “Quantum Theory Without Observers – Part I” – Physics
Today, v51, nº3, March 1998, https://doi.org/10.1063/1.882184 – Part II -
Physics Today, v51, nº4, April 1998, https://doi.org/10.1063/1.882241.

I do agree that quantum entanglement is a real phenomenon but the problem we have lies in the underlying physical description. We should not be thinking of the photons as two separate particles.

Instead, think of the entangled photons as a single system which is a dispersed wave in space (even when emitted from a distant star) then it is the act of the interaction of this dispersed wave with a detector which changes the state of the system and forces a particular outcome on another detector measuring the entangled pair.

This is explained in more detail here:

https://www.academia.edu/5927513/The_Spacetime_Wave_Theory

It does mean that there are instantaneous effects which take place when a wave system interacts with a detector. This does not mean that you can transmit information at faster than the speed of light because it only happens at the point of detection.

It does require us to understand the medium for the transmission of the change of state of the system and it is space time itself. Importantly, since we are talking about an instantaneous effect we have to state the frame of reference in which the instantaneous effect takes place since General Relativity (GR) tells us that instantaneous effects in one frame of reference are not instantaneous effects in another frame of reference.

This means that there must be a unique frame of reference in the universe for entanglement effects which seems to contradict the initial assumptions of GR but is not precluded by GR. It is proposed that this frame of reference is the same as the CMBR reference frame which is a cosmological unique frame of reference.

Why are we assuming that the "two" entangled particles are actually distinct at all?

It could easily be one multi-dimensional particle. Consider two circles. You observe one rotating clockwise. The other is 100% guaranteed to be rotating counter-clockwise. Seems mystical and magical until someone points out "The circles are cross sections of the same sphere." Step it up one dimension: Two apparently unconnected 3d sphere's, could be cross sections of the same 4d sphere.

And, that's keeping things pretty simple "just spheres". Those circles could've been cross sections of something more complicated: an egg, a cone, etc. The possibilities in 4-space are much more extensive, and it's entirely possible there's more than just 4. Why not? (Prove it! Ha!)

So, I figure (like ALL statistics): Quatum mechanics is just shorthand for "I don't know all the variables."
ALL particles are really just one multi-dimensional particle, viewed from different perspectives in 3-space. (That is: Gluons, photons, higgs and quarks etc,.....are all the same thing, they just appear different depending on the 3d cross section we happen to be witnessing.)

In fact, given infinite dimensions.....ALL of reality, every apparent particle, could actually be different 3d view points of two multidimensional particles. As the position of these two god-particles change with respect to the other, everything we observe changes. Complicated enough that we can only predict small windows of behavior. The rest, we just enumerate, average and report the statistic.

Non Locality has not been proven, the previous concepts of physics were disproven. Albert Einstein’s concept of a infesftesamaly small point “Knowing” what it is before it is even created and staying in that state for its entire existence is wrong. That is almost universally agreed upon; however there are huge problems with the “Bell Test” claims that it proves non locality.

The number one problem is that one can not use the polarization of photons to prove this; because we know for a fact that not only do photon’s “Know” their polarization before they are even detected but that polarization can change. It takes three polarized lenses that one can buy from any camera shop. Vertically orient one lens and then place a horizontal oriented lens in front of it and about 100% of the light is stopped. Now place a diagonally oriented lens in-between them and a 100% of the photons that made it through the first lens make it through the last. So on both points Einstein was wrong.

What does that tell us? Number one - our concept of time is wrong, or photons will react with the environment. Number two - Photons have to some how communicate with the environment.

What we get out of that is a particle has to be bigger then a infinitesimally small point but can only be “Detected” at one point. How big can they get? As strange as it might seem, it might be the size of the entire universe and that would give a “Optical Illusion” of non locality.

You, like virtually everyone else, claim that entanglement's effects have been seen in many experiments, but I've never once heard of an experiment where it was unambiguous that entanglement was occurring. Since I was an editor for articles being submitted for peer review for years, this isn't a minor thing.

One thing I saw frequently being confused with entanglement was simply the fact that the experiment used a large number of particles and the experiment designer was wrongfully abstracting that detail of the experiment away, effectively pretending to use only one.

A lingering problem with this experiment (there is more than one) is the assumption that the states of the particles are decided upon detection of one. The logic underpinning that assumption is far from airtight.

For an electron to be in a superposition of so called spin up and spin down isn't any more weird than for a person to be both north and east from their starting point. You can add orthogonal vectors, big whoop. Instead of pandering to sensationalism, why not do a video that explains how we are dealing with states described by unit vectors and how any such vectors can be decomposed into a combination of basis vectors without their being anything weird about it.

This video, like the vast majority of popular videos on the subject, does not accurately represent how the majority of physicists understand the phenomenon. The majority of physicists do not believe that there is any faster than light or instantaneous influence occurring in these experiments. The majority view is that the Bell Inequalities are not applicable to quantum systems as they are based on the assumption that incompatible observables can all be treated as subsets of a common set of states. In simple terms, the Bell inequalities are analogous to assuming one always has either a fist that is empty or a fist that is holding something even in the cases when your hand is actually open and you don't have a fist at all!

The mathematical structure that accurately captures incompatible observables and states of system with such observables is not a set of points and its subsets, but a Hilbert space of vectors and its subspaces - and that gives you quantum mechanics as opposed to statistical (ensemble) mechanics.

Spooky action at a distance only follows from quantum entanglement if you assume unidirectional time.

If drop that assumption, and instead allow the quantum wavefunctions to have bidirectional time, the whole mystery goes away: the state that the detectors will have at T=600 years simply influences the state at T=0.

The only mystery then would be why the quantum bidirectionality of time would not carry over to the macroscopic world, but since we don't know why the macroscopic world has unidirectional time anyways, this is not a problem.

Are you familiar with Conway-Kochen Free Will Theorem? It's a variation on the Kochen-Specker Theorem, whixh itself is a variation on Bell's Theorem.

While the authors use free will as a premise and claim their theorem proves that particles have free will, I think this is a gross error in philosophy made by a talented mathematician and a talented physicits (but not a philosopher who studies free will). Instead, in my opinion, what they actually showed is that there is a version of Bell's theorem that has no flaws so long as you don't accept that whatever random set you use to determine your settings correlates with the predictions of quantum mechanics. (Obviously not a precise defonition, the language usually used is that there is no "sensible" version of quantum mechanics, but that language doesn't fully convey ot either.)

You could use the digits of pi, a "random" number generator, the weather, anything you like. You could also use this dataset generated live by starlight. Unless every possible dataset you can use to generate your settings correlates perfectly to conspire to prevent a vioation of the inequality, then the true randomness in quantum mechanocs must be real.

To me, that was a much better use of Conway-Kochen and it defeats Bohm's theorem. The experiment in this video, while cool and useful and great for making videos like this, offers very little that is actually new.

What Schrodinger was really criticizing in his famous letter to Einstein that included the cat was the idea that there is something special about "observation". (And he was right, which is why we don't usually use that term in physics anymore, it leads to the misleading notions that Schrodinger criticized.)

Einstein had forgotten that he had previously said something very similar to Schrodinger and so Schrodinger was given credit. Einstein told him it was a brilliant idea, forgetting that Einstein had actually thought of it first.
